title: Thursday, 1st June, 2017
bodyHTML:
10:59 am
IK10:59am

...

IK11:00am

We're early I guess...

KS11:00am

One minute early

11:00 am
KS11:00am

Putting Bryce and Paul to shame

KS11:00am

(Weirdly enough, the tech has been absolutely fine for us)

IK11:00am

(Yeah, it is weird)

11:00 am
KS11:00am

(One would almost think they're using it as an excuse...)

KS11:00am

Ok, picture of the day

KS11:01am

11:00 am
KS11:01am

I was trying to find an interesting picture of the Bank of England

KS11:01am

But I couldn’t

KS11:01am

So I chose the most boring one possible

11:01 am
KS11:01am

Anyway…

KS11:01am

BoE staff are being ballotted today about whether they should go on strike

KS11:01am

A Reuters scoop

11:01 am
KS11:01am

http://uk.reuters....rike-idUKKBN18S45I

KS11:01am

Unite, Britain's biggest union, is consulting members on whether to take industrial action at the 323-year-old Bank, which employs around 3,600 people, after they were awarded a 1 percent pay rise for this year.

KS11:02am

Obviously they should, if only to give us something to write about...

11:02 am
IK11:02am

The Bank is so quaint.

IK11:02am

I love the way its staff have Bank of England debit cards.

KS11:03am

And properly funded pensions

11:03 am
IK11:03am

I heard a story about how they didn't originally have cheque guarantee stamps, and tesco check out staff wouldn't accept them.

IK11:03am

So they had to put them on just to make them more usable.

KS11:04am

@dodgson: every one on FT Alphaville is voting for the Wessex Regionalist Party

11:04 am
IK11:04am

but it was just "talk" so beware, could be fake news.

IK11:04am

ok... moving on

IK11:04am

should we talk about our favourite unicorn?

11:04 am
KS11:05am

Which is?

IK11:05am

UBERCORN

IK11:05am

@vixal BE and Paul are on hols.

11:05 am
undefined
IK11:06am

So the Ubercorn has been dominating headlines over night ... Kadhim give us the update

KS11:06am

So....

11:06 am
KS11:06am

They've lost another exec

KS11:06am

Which is obviously a good sign

IK11:06am

It's a big count now on the lost exec front

11:06 am
KS11:06am

This time their head of finance, Gautam Gupta

IK11:06am

They still don't have a CFO

KS11:07am

And we've got fresh financials

11:07 am
KS11:07am

https://www.wsj.co...-leaves-1496272500

KS11:07am

The ride-hailing company on Wednesday told The Wall Street Journal that first-quarter revenue was $3.4 billion, up 18% from the fourth quarter. Its loss, excluding employee stock compensation and other items, was $708 million, narrower than the $991 million reported three months earlier.

The company, which has raised some $15 billion in equity and debt funding, said it still has $7.2 billion of cash left on hand, about the same as it had at the end of last year.

IK11:08am

The NYT has the count at 10

11:08 am
KS11:08am

10 execs out in just a few months

IK11:09am

You can check them out here: https://www.nytime...-quarter.html?_r=0

IK11:09am

But what's also interesting is Buzzfeed's big scoop on the dysfunctionality of UberPool

11:09 am
IK11:09am

Now it is a personal theory of mine that UberPool is entirely pointless and only used by millennials who have more time than sense

KS11:09am

(@VIXAL: dw we've got public stocks in the schedule)

IK11:09am

Sorry Kadhim

11:10 am
IK11:10am

You need a taxi either because you are in a rush or because you just want to get home because you're drunk and sleepy

IK11:10am

The last thing you want is a diversion to pick someone else up

IK11:10am

Indeed, for this to be worthwhile the trip has to be basically free.

11:10 am
IK11:11am

So Buzzfeed's big scoop is that UberPool has to offer such immense discounts to get people to use it that guess what... it burns cash like an incinerator

IK11:11am

Here's the story

IK11:11am

https://www.buzzfe...l-burn-rate-frisco

11:11 am
IK11:11am

This bit here is my favourite

IK11:11am

“Match rate is key,” a former Uber employee who worked on Pool in another major US market told BuzzFeed News. “Burn is a direct result of a low match rate. The higher the match rate, the less the burn.”

When Uber first launched Pool in San Francisco, the service’s match rate was terribly low. According to internal metrics obtained by BuzzFeed News, just 3,600 of the 35,000 Pool trips completed in the week beginning Sept. 1, 2014, carried master-minion pairs. That's a match rate of just 7.9%.

IK11:12am

I mean seriously. This is literally Markets 101. I am just shocked that so many people with so much money don't understand basic liquidity/coincidence of wants stuff.

11:12 am
KS11:12am

Omg smile

IK11:12am

Look as far as I'm concerned the only "pool" ride that makes sense is on a fixed route, and involving more than 10 people - aka a bus

KS11:13am

Just one final thought on Uber, and then we'll get to Autotrader, mentioned on the right

11:13 am
KS11:13am

There was a Bloomberg story a while back

KS11:13am

Where they revealed their finances for the first time

KS11:13am

Well, revealed it on the record for the first time

11:13 am
KS11:13am

https://www.bloomb...as-losses-continue

KS11:13am

And they had this par

KS11:13am

Uber said it uses generally accepted accounting principles. Revenue includes only the portion Uber takes from fares, except in the case of its carpooling service; the company counts the entire amount of an UberPool fare as revenue. The more Uber’s business shifts to the multi-passenger service, the faster revenue grows. Non-GAAP revenue is significantly smaller. The loss statement doesn’t account for employee stock compensation, certain real-estate investments, automobile purchases and other expenses

11:13 am
KS11:14am

So… UberPool is accounted for differently than other Uber rides... Sort of weird, right?

KS11:14am

It seems to be related to this idea of an agent or principal. If you’re the principal in a transaction, you account for all of the revenue, and then you have cost of sales, and so on.

KS11:14am

So it looks like Uber is the principal for UberPool rides, rather than the agent. Which has implications for its relationship with its drivers, who it says are independent contractors

11:14 am
IK11:14am

@shinshin - disagree entirely. Using Uber on a daily basis for a commute is entirely cost prohibitive. It would need massive subsidies to work, hence why even buses don't make economic sense on many routes.

KS11:14am

*coughs, sorry

KS11:14am

Independent entrepreneurs

11:14 am
KS11:14am

But! It gets weirder

KS11:15am

Their spokesperson in the UK told me: “In the UK UberPOOL fares are accounted for in the same way as other Uber fares”.

KS11:15am

And then said

11:15 am
KS11:15am

The UberPOOL product operates differently around the world and therefore so does the way we account for it. In the US we must report Gross under US GAAP ASC606 due to the accounting rules put in place by the SEC. That's why it appears as it does in consolidated accounts.

IK11:15am

right. I also think it's all about how you get paid which determines whether you are a contractor or not. Mini cabs are decentralised contractors, but they use the dispatcher as a service, and pay them... not vice versa.

KS11:15am

They also said

11:15 am
KS11:15am

Under ASC605 agent v merchant determination is primarily based on economic risk. In the SEC's view our US Pool model made us the merchant under ASC605, hence our requirement to report US Pool revenues gross. Under the new ASC606 standard agent v merchant determination is based on an evaluation of control. As Uber does not control the goods or services in the US Pool transactions we anticipate reporting this revenue net going forwards, consistent with all other Uber trips.

Also the UK Pool model works in such a way that under both ASC605 and ASC606 Uber is deemed the agent by the SEC, hence it has and will be going forward stated on a net basis in the global consolidated accounts.

KS11:16am

There’s obviously a lot to be said about the idea that “Uber does not control the goods or services in the US Pool transactions”...

KS11:16am

And just a final point, here's the accounting change

11:16 am
KS11:16am

The old definition

KS11:16am

If an entity obtains control of the goods or services of another party before it transfers those goods or services to the customer, the entity’s performance obligation is to provide the goods or services itself. Hence, the entity is acting as a principal and should recognize revenue in the gross amount to which it is entitled. If an entity obtains legal title of a product only momentarily before legal title is transferred to the customer, the entity is not necessarily acting as a principal.

KS11:16am

And the new

11:16 am
IK11:16am

@shinshin it's cost prohibitive. Trust me. If it was breakeven, a non elite non banker would not be able to afford it.

KS11:16am

An entity is a principal if the entity controls a promised good or service before the entity transfers the good or service to a customer. However, an entity is not necessarily acting as a principal if the entity obtains legal title of a product only momentarily before legal title is transferred to a customer. An entity that is a principal in a contract may satisfy a performance obligation by itself or it may engage another party (for example, a subcontractor) to satisfy some or all of a performance obligation on its behalf. When an entity that is a principal satisfies a performance obligation, the entity recognizes revenue in the gross amount of consideration to which it expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods or services transferred.

KS11:17am

Smarter people than me can parse that I imagine

11:17 am
IK11:17am

So those questioning my take on the economics being non-cost effective should check out Hubert Horan's paper on all this.

IK11:18am

It was out earlier in May

IK11:18am

https://papers.ssr...bstract_id=2933177

11:18 am
IK11:18am

He's an actual transit expert, who -- you know -- has worked in the sector long enough to know the actual real world challenges with disrupting a sector which is already operating on a micro margin basis...

IK11:18am

Uber makes me mad, so perhaps we should move on?

KS11:19am

Lets go to Autotrader

11:19 am
undefined
Auto Trader Group PLC (AUTO:LSE): Last: 435.50, up 19.4 (+4.66%), High: 445.00, Low: 423.30, Volume: 5.30m
KS11:19am

Up on an upgrade from Barclays

11:19 am
KS11:19am

Results are due next Thursday

KS11:20am

Andrew Ross et all have a big 67-page note out

IK11:20am

@chad_john - it's cheap because it's subsidised! And because the drivers get totally gamed by Uber and most of them don't even make minimum wage. So yes, charity is cheap. And yes, most people like charity.

11:19 am
KS11:20am

In short: macro fears about the used car market are overdone

KS11:20am

Is the argument

KS11:20am

Let me give you some grey

11:20 am
KS11:20am

(Btw that's a really weird phrase to type out)

KS11:20am

Ahead of the FY results on 8 June, we are upgrading AutoTrader to Overweight and increasing our PT to 470p (on higher forecasts). This story has taken a sentiment hit due predominantly to perceived risk around exposure to weakening used car markets. This note explores this topic. There are risks in the outlook for used car pricing, but we do not expect wide forecourt closures. And even if that occurred, what matters most for AutoTrader are levels of used car stock. Here a decent outlook for used car transaction volumes should be a tailwind. We have also dug into new products: part exchange, financing and new cars. We think the latter two, in particular, will become meaningful contributors. The net of this is that we are now forecasting 10.0% ARPR growth in FY18E and 9.5% in FY19E, and we are 7% ahead of consensus EPS in FY18E. The stock has derated and on a FCF yield is starting to look attractive: 5.1% in cal 2018E for double-digit FCF growth. With gradual upgrades to consensus EPS as we go through FY18E, we see opportunity to rerate.

KS11:21am

Cyclical fears are overdone: UK consumer confidence is uncertain, new car volumes are peaking, and there are risks around falling used prices as PCP funded cars enter the used market, boosting supply. So it is logical that investors are concerned about the impact to AutoTrader. We believe used transaction volumes are likely to hold up, and our work on car dealers’ economics suggests that declining used pricing will only result in mass forecourt closures if the decline is rapid – not the base case. Regardless, our work on AutoTrader’s pricing model suggests that what matters the most to revenues by far is volume of stock, not the amount of forecourts (a point of debate amongst investors).

11:21 am
KS11:21am

And a bit more specifically on the cyclical fears

KS11:21am

We conclude that the environment for used car volumes is reasonably strong and we expect them to grow low to mid single digits in cal 2017E. New car volumes are rolling over, however, and that could mean used car volumes are flattish in cal 2018E, or could even turn slightly negative in a worse case. But that is no disaster, in our view. We have more concerns on used car pricing and there are some good arguments as to why pricing may come under some pressure with supply increasing sharply in the younger car categories. But our view is that any decline in pricing will be relatively gradual unless the increasing supply is matched with a collapse in consumer confidence, which is not the base case (severe bears on UK macro may not be appealed to this recommendation). And that environment should be manageable for the majority of dealers, who today are making healthy margins in many cases. We do not expect wide forecourt closures. We stress than the UK is not the US – the quality of borrower is higher, the level at which residuals are accounted for is more conservative, OEMs have said they will try to preserve pricing and used car pricing is not declining rapidly (and not expected to by industry experts).

And our work on AutoTrader’s exposure to the cycle suggests what matters most is stock - a function of used transaction volumes not pricing - not forecourt numbers. Dealership consolidation isn’t helpful (at the margin scale brings bargaining power) but the vast majority of the ARPR is linked to stock. So if modest consolidation occurs without a decline in used car transaction volumes, then our work suggests the impact is very manageable. We believe investors are overly concerned on this aspect of the AutoTrader story

IK11:22am

So I have no real opinions about autotrader because my sibling is in the second hand car market...

11:22 am
KS11:22am

@Lefevre: tbh that's what's happening in some US towns. They're closing bus routes and giving people discounted Uber rides

KS11:23am

In the second hand car market as in, a dealer or someone who just likes second hand cars?

IK11:23am

IK11:25am

Takeaway technology firm Deliveroo is offering its drivers the option to be paid for each order they deliver, rather than per hour - a move which the company hopes will reinforce the riders’ status as self-employed contractors, rather than employees.

11:25 am

undefined
11:26 am

Thumbs up

IK11:27am

Trading is down,...

IK11:27am

https://www.reuter...ocks-idUSKBN18R2DP

11:27 am
IK11:28am

From Reuters

IK11:28am

JPMorgan's trading revenue has fallen 15 percent so far in the second quarter, its chief financial officer, Marianne Lake, told investors at a conference. She would not provide a prediction for June.
Bank of America Chief Executive Officer Brian Moynihan, meanwhile, told investors the bank's second-quarter trading revenue would be lower than a year ago.
"It's especially difficult because of the year-over-year comparison. The first and second quarter in 2016 were fairly busy on the trading front," said R.J. Grant, head of trading at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods in New York.
Investors were disappointed that JPMorgan's CFO did not predict a turnaround for June, Grant said.
"People are digging in for a bit of a slower summer here," he said. "If the big banks don't see anything on the horizon, then it potentially does not bode well for others. Volatility is non-existent. It's difficult to generate trading volumes or commissions or when the VIX is at historically low levels."

KS11:28am

So the Trump-flated boom times...

10:59 am
IK10:59am

Hello rabble

KS11:29am

I for one am shocked

IK11:29am

Supposedly not

11:28 am
KS11:29am

shocked I tells ya

IK11:29am

And the banks ain't gonna be rocketing to the moon with bitcoin

IK11:29am

But closer to home we have some relief on the Italian banking front

11:29 am
IK11:30am

Reuters again

IK11:30am

BRUSSELS, June 1 (Reuters) - The European Commission has reached an initial agreement with Italian authorities over a recapitalisation of troubled lender Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena BMPS.MI, the European Union's competition watchdog said on Thursday.
The Commission said it had agreed in principle on the "precautionary recapitalisation" of the bank in line withEU rules, provided that certain criteria are met such as making sure the bank becomes profitable.
"It would allow Italy to inject capital into MPS as a precaution, in line with EU rules, whilst limiting the burden on Italian taxpayers," Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager said in a statement.
Italy's fourth biggest bank had 26 billion euros ($29 billion) in gross defaulting debts at the end of last year said it was in exclusive talks with a domestic fund and a group of investors over the sale of its bad loan portfolio.

IK11:31am

So perhaps Italy won't break europe now?

11:32 am
undefined
KS11:32am

If it's not too self indulgent

KS11:32am

Let's do a quick dive into something media-ish

11:32 am
KS11:32am

Specifically the New York Times canning its public editor

KS11:33am

And deciding that the People on the Social Medias are just as good at keeping their journalists in check

KS11:33am

The public editor position, created in the aftermath of a grave journalistic scandal, played a crucial part in rebuilding our readers’ trusts by acting as our in-house watchdog. We welcomed that criticism, even when it stung. But today, our followers on social media and our readers across the internet have come together to collectively serve as a modern watchdog, more vigilant and forceful than one person could ever be. Our responsibility is to empower all of those watchdogs, and to listen to them, rather than to channel their voice through a single office.

We are dramatically expanding our commenting platform. Currently, we open only 10 percent of our articles to reader comments. Soon, we will open up most of our articles to reader comments. This expansion, made possible by a collaboration with Google, marks a sea change in our ability to serve our readers, to hear from them, and to respond to them.

11:33 am
KS11:33am

that's the memo, from here http://www.niemanl...e-sulzberger-memo/

IK11:33am

so clearly I'm in a bad mood or something

IK11:33am

I think this is crazy. If vigilante comment moderating worked then Facebook and Twitter would not be having to invest ever greater sums in real person content moderation.

11:34 am

KS11:34am

11:34 am

You know the sort, Paul Murphy intervening and saying: your language is abusive and we won’t tolerate this sort of stuff. Paul Murphy spends at least a fifth of his day reviewing comments. According to the NY Times tho he’s going to have more time to lunch from now on.

IK11:35am

Ok, so basically i think this is a bad day for journalism.

FirstGroup PLC (FGP:LSE): Last: 141.60, down 8.2 (-5.47%), High: 149.50, Low: 134.40, Volume: 3.04m

IK11:37am

@lefevre - i had a bit of a frantic night yesterday chasing a potential fintech scoop, but it was shut down. But i suggest watch this space. I think news is coming about the viability of blockchain.

KS11:37am

Full year results for the year to 31 March 2017 were better than expected, primarily due to better performances in North America. Net cash inflow was £147m (£36m before franchise outflows). The share price has risen strongly in recent months, up 22% since it announced the South Western rail franchise win on 25 March and supported by a stronger dollar. The company, however, continues to carry a significant debt burden and cash inflows are expected to be held back by the need for ongoing pension payments in excess of P&L charges (£38m in 2017 and could rise going forward). With a dividend reinstatement likely for 2018 and beyond, the ability to make bolt-on acquisitions in North America in order to supplement contract losses appears relatively restricted if the company aims to reduce debt levels materially.

Profit expectations for UK Bus, Transit and Greyhound remain sluggish in the near term and First Student profit growth is likely to decelerate as margins approach 10% and the ability to achieve further contract price increases diminishes (First Student accounted for 44% of group operating profit in 2017). UK Rail should clearly benefit from the SWT franchise win, although underlying market conditions in UK rail remain challenging. The shares are trading at a prospective P/E of 11.6x, a 24% premium to its 5 year historical average

Intelsat SA plans to announce its bondholders have rejected a proposal to combine the satellite operator with SoftBank Group Corp.’s OneWeb Ltd., which will likely lead to the deal’s termination, according to a person familiar with the matter.

The bondholders have been haggling over the price they would receive in the deal and the parties could not reconcile their differences, said the person, asking not to be identified because the matter is private. SoftBank has already begun talks with alternative satellite partners, including Inmarsat plc, said the person. Other prospects include Telesat Holdings Inc. and SES SA, the person said.

The company is guiding to better underlying revenue growth than the street expects (6% ex FX vs 4-5%) but is pointing out that one-offs will present a negative £16m tailwind (+£13m FX, -£12m due to lower pension discount rates, -£17m non recurring US healthcare credits). The pension headwind was not in analyst numbers and may prompt small downgrades. Analyst meet at 9.30am.

KS11:54am

We welcome Barclays’ “upsized” disposal of a 33.7% stake in Barclays Africa (Not Rated), which (after 1.5% for black economic empowerment) cuts its holding to 14.9%. This should prove sufficient to achieve regulatory deconsolidation, adding 73bps to CET1 capital. We calculate the Q1 2017 CET1 ratio, pro forma for (1) the completed Egypt disposal and (2) deconsolidation of Barclays Africa, at 13.3%. Given such capital strength, we urge Barclays to make the EPS-enhancing pref call without delay. BUY.

Barclays has sold 285.7m shares (a 33.7% stake) via an accelerated book-build at a price of ZAR132 per share, a 5% discount to last night’s close (and the shares had already fallen during the day). No matter – we still see this deal as utterly transformational for Barclays’ capital position, which in turn offers specific opportunities for earnings enhancement, and (at least) underpins our existing expectation for a material step-up in the 2018e dividend.

Barclays’ CET1 capital ratio was 12.45% at Q1 2017. The Egypt disposal added 10bps, and last night’s placing in itself adds a further 27bps, raising CET1 to a highly respectable 12.82%. Moreover, full deconsolidation should add a further 46bps, raising CET1 to pro forma 13.3%, affording new flexibility.

IK11:59am

In some cases, collateral that has been pledged simply doesn't exist. In others, it disappears as borrowers in financial distress sell the assets. There are also instances in which the same collateral has been pledged to multiple lenders. One lawyer said he discovered that the same pile of steel was used to secure loans from 10 different lenders.

With the mainland facing its slowest growth in over a quarter of a century, defaults are mounting as borrowers struggle to repay their loans. The danger of fraudulent collateral in this situation, say economists, is that it exacerbates the problem of bad debt for China's banks, increasing the risk of financial turmoil.
